title: 109_s2424
content: Increase in contribution limits for Health Savings Accounts. Increase in Monthly Limit for Health Savings Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for individuals with coverage under a high deductible health plan. The monthly limitation is \1/12 \of the annual deductible and out-of-pocket expenses required for covered benefits. The text discusses the dollar amounts for self-only and family coverage under a high deductible health plan. It also mentions special rules for reducing out-of-pocket expenses for eligible individuals with separate plans. The Secretary may provide regulations to exclude annual out-of-pocket expenses under certain conditions. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code to align with the changes. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding special rules for married individuals and disregarding certain items in computing monthly limitations for health plans. The combined marital limit for married individuals is the excess of the sum of limitations for each spouse or a specified dollar amount. The combined marital limit for married individuals is the excess of the sum of limitations for each spouse or a specified dollar amount. For tax purposes, if both spouses have family coverage under the same plan, they are treated as having only that coverage. A spouse's applicable share is typically one-half of the combined marital limit unless both spouses have different family coverage plans. The IRS sets the combined marital limit for married individuals based on the sum of limitations for each spouse or a specified dollar amount. If both spouses have family coverage under the same plan, they are considered to have only that coverage. A spouse's share is usually half of the combined marital limit unless they have different family coverage plans. Rules are in place for couples not married for the entire year to calculate the combined marital limit. The term 'family coverage' refers to any coverage other than self-only coverage. If multiple individuals are covered by a high deductible health plan but only one is eligible, it is considered self-only coverage. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2006.
